subject: Re: [junit] Design documentation for JUnit 4.x?
msgSnippet: Well, I tried that now. It is not the kind of documentation I meant. Such tools just twist and twirl data and present it in a way which does not help much to
messageBody:
Well, I tried that now. It is not the kind of documentation I meant.

Such tools just twist and twirl data and present it in a way which does not help much to understand the design.

A good documentation cannot be automated away or roundtripped.

You need some text and some diagrams. Both need not be perfect. But as I said, that can't be automated, or at least is not valuable for understanding it quickly as it would be from a human who knows how man thinks and how the design is and what does matter to know and what is unnecessary detail.

But it seems no matter what I would write, you mean that there will be no such manual documentation. A little design documentation would be very good for understanding such a widely used tool. Thousands of programmers should not need to download a specific tool and then discover that it does not help them understanding JUnit's design.

Just my opinion.


--- On Thu, 10/23/08, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
From: David Saff <david@...>
Subject: Re: [junit] Design documentation for JUnit 4.x?
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thursday, October 23, 2008, 1:45 PM











None published.



If someone wanted to download a trial copy of Structure 101 and

produce some, that'd be cool, and I'd be happy to answer questions.



David Saff

<hans_schwaebli@ yahoo.com> wrote:
